What´s happening here is a simple example of Lenz´s law. When you drop a magnet trough copper or even aluminum as it moves through it creates current, and part of the current is what we call Foucault current and it goes in opposite direction of the magnet pushing it up thus slowing it. So you are perfectly correct on that, however the question: Is copper magnetic is a bit tricky, yes and no. It is not magnetic in the common sense like Cobalt,Nickel and Iron, but it is magnetic. It is diamagnetic which means it repels the magnet, but the force of repulsion is so low that it´s next to zero. So both answers are pretty much correct.

If you look at most new coasters, they have 2 different styles of brakes. One of these is a simple bracket - no moving parts - that has two rectangular magnets held apart so there is a very strong magnetic field between them. A non-ferrous (meaning it doesn't attract a magnet) plate or fin is bolted to each coaster car to pass between those magnets. They are placed so they never touch.

When the train moves quickly into the brake run, it creates those electrical eddy currents, resisting the movement of the train, and thus slowing it down. But it can't really stop the train completely, just slow it down a lot because these eddy currents' strength is proportional to the speed. Too slow, and they can't create electricity or force. So they add one traditional friction brake to actually stop the train.

It gets a bit nuts when you think of the implications. One of the big coasters to use this technique is Millennium Force in Cedar Point. Once the train goes over the lift, there aren't any brakes until the end, and this is a 300 foot roller coaster. It goes fast. But the last brake run has a whole lot of these bracket and magnet combos to slow the train. The only thing that actually stops this train that a moment ago was going 60+ MPH? A single rubber wheel.

If you take it to the extreme, the cylindrical tower and ring style drop towers operate on the same principle. The magnets and fins swap places, so the magnets are on the ring that is dropped, and the fins are bolted to the tower. When the ring is dropped with all its passengers, there is nothing but a couple guide wheels attaching it to the tower, and it falls in very close to free fall. The only thing that slows this ring down from crashing into the ground from some 200 feet is a braking system that never even touches the ring (!!!). A few pistons at the bottom cushion the last bit of energy, and you are safe on the ground again. And don't worry about it failing. Not only are there a bunch of these to make it redundant, if the ride could last this long, it would be safe for human passengers for the next 700 years (yes, seven hundred) before you would have to replace the magnets once.

As long as you remember that electricity and magnetism go hand in hand, it's all pretty simple. Electric flow- movement of electrons- creates (relatively small) magnetic waves, and similarly, magnetic waves produce a small electric flow.

So by dropping the magnet down the copper pipe, it will create a small electric flow in the pipe, the electrons in the copper begin to oscillate in small eddy currents, which in turn generate their own tiny magnetic field that weakly opposes the magnetic field of the magnet. Done.

When the neodymium magnet falls through the copper pipe, and the magnetic field of the magnet is changing it's velocity, eddy currents, which are basically electrons moving in circles due to a Lorentz force, are created inside the pipe. These currents have electrical charge and induce an electromagnetic field on the magnet, which puts an upward force and resistance on the magnet, slowing it down.
